body: Determine if the relation $R = \{(x, y) \in A : 3x - y = 0\}$ is reflexive, symmetric, and transitive for $A = \{1, 2, 3, \dots, 14\}$.
Check if the relation $R = \{(a, b) : b = a + 1\}$ in the set $A = \{1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6\}$ is reflexive, symmetric, or transitive.
Show that the relation $R = \{(x, y) : x - y \text{ is an integer}\}$ is an equivalence relation in $\mathbb{Z}$.
In a set of all books in a library, define the relation $R = \{(x, y) : x \text{ and } y \text{ have the same number of pages}\}$. Show that $R$ is an equivalence relation.
Verify if the relation $R = \{(a, b) : |a - b| \text{ is even}\}$ is an equivalence relation on the set $A = \{1, 2, 3, 4, 5\}$.
Show that the relation $R = \{(P, Q) : \text{distance of } P \text{ from the origin is the same as the distance of } Q \text{ from the origin}\}$ is an equivalence relation.
Let $R$ be a relation in the set of all polygons, defined as $R = \{(P_1, P_2) : P_1 \text{ and } P_2 \text{ have the same number of sides}\}$. Prove that $R$ is an equivalence relation.
In the set of natural numbers $\mathbb{N}$, define the relation $R = \{(x, y) : y = x + 5 \text{ and } x < 4\}$. Determine if $R$ is reflexive, symmetric, or transitive.
Given the relation $R = \{(x, y) : x^2 = y^2\}$ in the set of integers $\mathbb{Z}$, determine if $R$ is an equivalence relation.
Prove that the relation $R = \{(x, y) : x \text{ and } y \text{ live in the same city}\}$ is an equivalence relation in a set of people.
If $R = \{(a, b) : a \text{ and } b \text{ belong to the same department in a company}\}$, show that $R$ is an equivalence relation.
Consider the function $f : \mathbb{R} \to \mathbb{R}$ defined by $f(x) = x^2$. Prove or disprove that $f$ is injective and/or surjective.
For a set $X = \{1, 2, 3, 4\}$, examine if the function $f : X \to X$ defined by $f(x) = x$ is bijective.
Verify that the function $f : \mathbb{R} \to \mathbb{R}$ defined by $f(x) = 2x + 3$ is bijective.
Show that the function $f : \mathbb{Z} \to \mathbb{Z}$ defined by $f(x) = x + 1$ is a bijection.
Let $f : \mathbb{N} \to \mathbb{N}$ be defined by $f(x) = 3x + 1$. Determine if $f$ is one-one and/or onto.
Show that the function $f : \mathbb{N} \to \mathbb{N}$ given by $f(x) = x^3$ is injective.
Consider the function $f : \mathbb{R} \to \mathbb{R}$ defined by $f(x) = \cos(x)$. Is $f$ injective, surjective, or bijective?
If $f : \mathbb{Z} \to \mathbb{Z}$ is given by $f(x) = x^2$, determine if $f$ is one-one and/or onto.
For the function $f : \mathbb{R} \to \mathbb{R}$ defined by $f(x) = |x|$, is $f$ injective, surjective, or bijective?
Determine if the function $f : \mathbb{R} \to \mathbb{R}$ defined by $f(x) = x + 5$ is bijective.
